citeinfo.title: Areas of Predicted Aquifer Decline Greater than 50% of Available Head - Twin Cities Metropolitan Area, Minnesota

descript.abstract:
This dataset illustrates areas where 2030 and 2050 projected aquifer drawdown in currently confined portions of the Prairie du Chien-Jordan and Franconia-Ironton-Galesville aquifers is expected to reduce available head by more than 50% within the Twin Cities metropolitan area. Reductions in available head greater than 50% may signal future water supply limitations if aquifer withdrawals continue to increase. Aquifer drawdown was predicted using Metropolitan Council water demand projections and a regional groundwater flow model of the Twin Cities metropolitan area (Metro Model 2) developed for the Council by Barr Engineering Company.
More information about this process is provided in the 2009 Metropolitan Council report 'Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan', which is available online at www.metrocouncil.org/environment/WaterSupply/metrogroundwatermodeldatasets.htm.
descript.purpose: The 2005 Minnesota Legislature directed the Metropolitan Council to "carry out planning activities addressing the water supply needs of the metropolitan area" (Minnesota Statutes, Section 473.1565). Specifically the Council is charged with developing a base of technical information for water supply planning decisions and to prepare a metropolitan area master water supply plan. This dataset supports this charge.
descript.supplinf: Twin Cities metropolitan area including the counties of Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Ramsey, Scott and Washington in Minnesota

timeperd.current: Data is based upon Metropolitan Council population projections developed in 2006 and a regional groundwater flow model calibration completed in Spring 2009.

place.placekey: Twin Cities, Anoka County, Carver County, Dakota County, Hennepin County, Ramsey County, Scott County, Washington County, Minnesota

theme.themekey: water supply planning, available head, Prairie du Chien-Jordan, Franconia-Ironton-Galesville, Metro Model 2, groundwater

idinfo.useconst: By acceptance of this data, the user agrees to include a copy of the metadata record, including the liability disclaimer, whenever the user transmits or provides the GIS data (or any portion of it) to another user.

citeinfo.title:
Datasets described by this metadata:
drawhdfra2030 drawhdfra2050 drawhdpdc2030 drawhdpdc2050

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.1.1332

cntinfo.cntpos: Sr. Environmental Scientist, Water Supply Planning

dataqual.complete: The entire seven county geographic area is covered

procstep.procdesc:
PROCESS: 2030 and 2050 water demand was projected for each municipality or municipal water supply system in the Twin Cities metropolitan area using the method described in Appendix E of the 2009 Metropolitan Council report 'Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan'.
Model results were exported as ESRI Spatial Analyst raster files and used to calculate where the modeled aquifer elevation is less than 50% available head, as defined by:
Projection Year Aquifer Water Elevation - (Calibration Year Aquifer Water Elevation - (50% (Calibration Year Aquifer Water Elevation - Aquifer Bedrock Surface)))
Results were clipped to areas where the aquifer is considered to be currently confined, as defined by:
Aquifer Water Level Elevation - Aquifer Bedrock Surface > 3.048 meters
3. 048 meters was selected instead of 0.000 meters as the threshold to define confined conditions, because it allows for some natural variability in aquifer water levels to cause seasonal shifts from confined to unconfined conditions in areas where existing available head is very small.

stdorder.ordering:
This dataset is distributed on the internet by clicking below after 'Online Linkage'. Doing so will tell your browser to download a 'ZIP' file which will contain the following:
- ArcView shape files - metadata for the dataset (.htm) - NOTICE.RTF, an important notice about this dataset that can be read by any word processing software.
This dataset can also be viewed and downloaded from the MetroGIS DataFinder Cafe at http://www.datafinder.org/cafe/ . The Cafe allows users to subset or clip datasets using an existing feature, such as a city or school district boundary or an ad-hoc, user defined area.
Additionally, this dataset is available for direct use via one or more map services. More information about what a web mapping service is can be found at http://www.datafinder.org/services/ . The specific map service and layer name for this dataset can be found by clicking the blue or green boxes under the map service column of the DataFinder Catalog at http://www.datafinder.org/catalog/ .
